key_points: More than 20,000 National Guard members expected in Washington to secure President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.
US Secret Service officially in charge of Biden's inauguration security.
Concerns rise over the possibility of improvised explosive devices (IEDs) being used in unrest related to the inauguration.
FBI Director Chris Wray and federal officials warn of extremists at planned rallies and potential violence.
Security perimeters expanding around Capitol, White House, and National Naval Observatory.
Massive security involving coordination among the Secret Service, federal law enforcement agencies, and the Pentagon.
Total request for National Guard support close to 30,000, with an expected final need of approximately 20,000.
The number of National Guard members for the inauguration exceeds the number of active-duty US troops in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria combined.
Discussions underway about possibly raising the national terror threat level.
Secret Service leads inauguration security efforts amid concerns of increased potential for attacks following Capitol breach.
spokespersons: Ken Cuccinelli (DHS Senior Official performing the duties of the Deputy Secretary)
